Graphical abstract Nanocrystalline MgO has been synthesized by simple hydrothermal method and it showed excellent catalytic activity and recyclibility for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by chemical fixation of CO2 on epoxides and N-formylation of amines by using HCO2H as reagent at room temperature. Chemical fixation of CO2 into fine chemicals is one of the key areas of research today to mitigate greenhouse gas CO2 and its successful utilization as C1 building block. Nanocrystalline MgO has been synthesized by simple precipitation method followed by calcination at 450 °C. The materials are characterized thoroughly by several instrumental tools, which suggested the presence of mesoscopic void space and excellent catalytic activity for the synthesis of organic cyclic carbonates by chemical fixation of CO2 on a wide range of epoxides at atmospheric pressure and room temperature within a short reaction time. Maximum product yields upto 99% for the cyclic carbonates are observed. It also displayed a high catalytic activity in the N-formylation of various amines by using formic acid as reagent (acts both as carbon source and reducing agent) at room temperature with excellent product yields upto 99.5%. This nanocrystalline MgO material showed high recycling efficiency for the cycloaddition of CO2 onto the epoxides and no sign of catalyst deactivation. Keywords MgO nanostructure CO2 fixation Cyclic carbonates N-formylation reaction 1 Introduction Development of efficient catalytic processes for the fixation of carbon dioxide (CO2) into the reactive substrates for the synthesis of desirable and economically sustainable chemicals is one of the frontline areas of research today as it can provide a valuable route to mitigate the primary greenhouse gas CO2, responsible for anthropogenic global warming and climate change [1,2]. Since CO2 is both kinetically and thermodynamically stable and moderately reactive, catalytic conversions involving CO2 as C1 reagent is very attractive not only from environmental perspective but from economical point of view also [3–8]. Thus, it is a green alternative to reduce carbon emissions and a sustainable building block for fine chemical synthesis. In this context, the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2 is a promising methodology because of high atom efficiency of the process and owing to their high solubility, boiling and flash points, low toxicities and biodegradability. Further, these carbonates have been extremely useful as aprotic polar solvents, polymeric and organic synthesis and ingredients in fine chemicals like dialkyl carbonates, glycols, carbamates, pyrimidines, purines and pharmaceuticals in biomedical synthesis [9–13]. Several porous catalysts, such as simple metal oxides, Schiff bases, salen complexes, and supported ionic liquid can catalyse this reaction of epoxides with CO2 [14–18]. This CO2 fixation reaction on epoxides can proceeds catalytically at high temperature (>100 °C) and pressure (>10 atm) to produce cyclic carbonates in a desirable yield [19–21]. Metal oxides, titanosilicates, zeolites, supported metal complexes and polyoxometalates are intensively studied as catalyst for this chemical transformation [22–26]. Nevertheless, still this reaction suffers from several limitations, either due to the diminished reactivity for several reaction cycles or harsh reaction conditions, high CO2 pressure or longer duration for the completion of the reaction. Thus, CO2 fixation reactions at milder conditions (i.e., low temperature and pressure) in the presence of a simple catalytic system are still remain challenging [27,28]. Recently several reports on the adsorption of CO2 onto the surface of magnesium oxide [29] prompted us to employ nanocrystalline MgO for this CO2 fixation reaction. Activation of CO2 molecules over MgO surface [30] has motivated us to explore its reaction with terminal epoxides for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. In this context it is also pertinent to mention that formylation of amines has been studied intensively over the years due to the high utility of the N-formylated compounds in several industrial processes [31]. The resulting formamides serve as valuable intermediates for the construction of various pharmaceutically important compounds [32]. Numerous methods are available today for the N-formylation of amines, which includes the use of in-situ formed formic anhydride [33], acetic-formic anhydride [34], chloral [35], KF-Al2O3 formic acid (FA)-DCC [36] or EDCI [37], activated formic esters [38], ammonium formate [39], and formic acid in polyethylene glycol [40], aq. 85% formic acid with ZnO [41]. Recently, ZnCl2, FeCl3, AlCl3, NiCl2 and sulfonic acid supported hydroxyapatite encapsulated γ-Fe2O3 has been reported as efficient catalysts [42] for the N-formylation reaction. However, toxicity of the reaction systems, high reaction time and temperatures, poor chemical stability, formation of side products are the major drawbacks for these reactions. Further, FA used as reagent for this N-formylation reaction can be synthesized very efficiently through the photo/electrochemical reduction or catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 [43]. Thus, FA is a sustainable reagent for the N-formylation reaction. In recent years, functionalized porous nanomaterials are frequently employed as adsorbents [44,45] and catalysts [46–48] due to their large surface area-to-volume ratio and abundance of both surface acid and base sites [49]. Since the synthesis of MgO based nanomaterial is very simple and economical, exploring its catalytic potential using CO2 or HCO2H as a reagent can be very useful as far as sustainability of the catalytic process is concerned [50]. Thus, here we report the MgO based nanomaterial through a simple precipitation method and explored its catalytic activity for the synthesis of organic cyclic carbonates through CO2 fixation reaction on a wide range of epoxides under ambient reaction conditions. This MgO nanomaterial also catalyzes the N-formylation of various types of amines with formic acid as reagent with excellent product yields at room temperature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Magnesium nitrate hexahydrate [Mg(NO3)2,6H2O], ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH, 25% aqueous), sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)were purchased from Merck, India. Commercial available MgO, all epoxides, amines, formic acid (98%) and solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All reagents and solvents were distilled through standard process and dried before use. Deionized (DI) water was used for all the experiments wherever needed. 2.2 Synthesis of MgO nanomaterial The magnesium oxide nanomaterial was synthesized from the aqueous magnesium nitrate solution through ammonia precipitation method. 0.01 mol aqueous solution of magnesium nitrate hexahydrate was taken in a round bottom flask and a calculated amount of an aqueous ammonium hydroxide solution was added to the magnesium nitrate solution dropwise under continuous stirring at room temperature. The NH4OH to Mg mole ratio was maintained at 6:1. A white precipitate was obtained. Then the bottle was closed tightly and the mixture was stirred magnetically at 65 °C for 5 h. After 5 h, the heating was stopped and the mixture was stirred slowly for the next 18 h at room temperature. The precipitate was then collected by centrifugation followed by repeated washing with DI water, dried at 70 °C for 4 h. A part of this as prepared sample was calcined at 450 °C for 4 h to get the desired MgO nanomaterial. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the sample was studied by a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using the Ni-filtered Cu Kα (λ= 0.15406 nm) radiation. The thermal stability of the MgO nanomaterial was measured by differential thermal analysis (DTA) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Netzsch STA 449C, Germany) from 30 to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under air atmosphere. The characteristic vibration bands of the samples were collected by a Perkin-Elmer FT-IR 783 spectrophotometer taking the sample in a KBr pellet. The N2 adsorption-desorption analysis of MgO sample was conducted by using a ASIQ MP BET analyser, Quantachrome Instruments, USA at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K). Prior to the measurement the sample was outgassed in vacuum for 4 h at 200 °C. The total surface area was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method within the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.05-0.20. The pore size distribution was estimated by using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The total pore volume was calculated from the amount of N2 adsorbed at the relative pressure (P/P0) of ca. 0.99. For the TPD-CO2 analysis the sample was inserted into the U-type glass cell and subjected for outgassing under helium gas to remove any surface adsorbed moisture. Then it was cooled down to room temperature and CO2 gas was purged through the sample for 30 min followed by purging of helium gas for 45 min to get rid of excess CO2 gas from the cell. With increasing temperature at 5 °C per min the TCD signal has been obtained. The morphology and nanostructure of MgO material were analyzed by using a JEOL JEM 2010 ultra high resolution transmission electron microscope (UHR TEM) operating at 200 kV. At the end of the reactions, the reaction products were studied via a Varian 3400 gas chromatograph equipped with a 30 m CP-SIL 8CB capillary column and a flame ionization detector. The reaction products were identified by Trace DSQ II GC–MS equipped with a 60 m TR-50MS capillary column. 2.4 Synthesis of cyclic carbonates over MgO nanomaterial Cyclic carbonate conversion from the respective epoxide was carried out by mixing 2 mmol epoxide, 1 mmol Bu4NBr and 25 mg MgO catalyst in a 50 ml round bottom flask, fitted with rubber stopper pierced by a balloon, which contained CO2 under 1 atmosphere. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. At the end of the reaction, the work up was done by adding ethylacetate to the reaction mixture. After that the solid insoluble catalyst part was centrifuged out and the organic solvent part was collected. The collected organic part was washed with H2O and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The desired product was obtained after evaporating the solvent and studied by GC analysis to determine the yield of the cyclic carbonate product. The epoxide to the respective cyclic carbonate conversion was monitored by the gas chromatographic technique to optimize the reaction time. 2.5 MgO catalysed N-formylation of amines N-formylation of amine was carried out by treating 1 mmol of aniline with 3 mmol formic acid in 8 ml acetonitrile in the presence of 60 mg of MgO catalyst in a 50 ml round bottom flask, fitted with a magnetic stirrer. The reaction was carried out at room temperature for 20 min. At the end of the reaction, the work up was done by adding ethylacetate to the reaction mixture. After that the solid insoluble catalyst part was centrifuged out and the organic solvent part was collected. The collected organic part was washed with H2O and saturated NaHCO3 solution and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The desired product was obtained after evaporating the solvent and studied by GC analysis to determine the yield of the product. The progress of the amine to respective the N-formamide conversion was monitored by the GC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of MgO materials 3.1.1 Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis The PXRD pattern of the as-prepared Mg(OH)2 material is shown in Fig. 1 (a). This pattern resembles well with the characteristics diffraction pattern of magnesium hydroxide [Mg(OH)2, JCPDS:84-2163], which is on calcination at 450 °C gives MgO. The wide angle powder XRD pattern of MgO sample is shown in Fig. 1(b). As noticed from Fig. 1b there are five diffraction peaks, which appeared at 2θ value of 36.6°, 42.6°, 62.0°, 74.2° and 78.3°. These diffraction peaks could be attributed to the corresponding characteristic diffraction planes 111, 200, 220, 311 and 222, respectively of cubic MgO phase [51]. This diffraction pattern matched well with the JCPDS card no 01-1235, suggesting the presence of crystalline cubic MgO phase in our MgO nanomaterial. Further, the powder XRD pattern of the reused MgO material after 5 reaction cycles is shown in Fig. 1c. As seen from this pattern that the MgO material has retained its crystalline cubic phase after 5 reaction cycles, although the intensity of the peaks somewhat decreased. 3.1.2 FTIR analysis The FTIR spectra of the as-prepared and the calcined MgO samples are shown in Fig. 2 . The intense peak at 3695 cm−1 and the broad peak at 3450 cm−1 in the FTIR spectra of the as-prepared sample could be assigned to structural and surface adsorbed hydroxyl groups, respectively [45]. The 3695 cm−1 band completely disappeared in the case of calcined sample due decomposition of Mg(OH)2 to MgO. The absorption band at 1648 cm−1 could be attributed to bending vibration mode of physisorbed water molecules for both as-prepared and calcined sample. The characteristic Mg-O vibration bands between 900 and 400 cm−1 confirmed the presence of MgO phase in the calcined sample [52]. 3.1.3 Thermogravimetric (TG) and Differential thermal analysis (DTA) The TG-DTA plots of the as-prepared Mg(OH)2 sample are shown in Fig. 3 . The TG analysis showed that the mass loss of the sample occurred in two significant steps. The first step is upto 320 °C with 6% mass loss and the second step is from 320 to 450 °C with 31.5% mass loss. After 450 °C temperature there is no significant weight loss. The first step mass loss corresponds to the removal of surface adsorbed water indicating endothermic peak at around 120 °C in the DTA plot. The second step mass loss corresponds to the thermal decomposition of the as-prepared sample i.e. dehydroxylation of Mg(OH)2 indicating the endothermic peak at 358 °C in the DTA plot [53]. The predicted theoretical mass loss of 30.9% calculated from the stoichiometric conversion of Mg(OH)2 to MgO phase and the second step mass loss of 31.5% obtained from the TGA plot are almost similar. Thus, the thermal dehydration of Mg(OH)2 to MgO can be written as follows: Mg(OH)2 → MgO + H2O (320°–450 °C) 3.1.4 Surface area measurement The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the MgO material are shown in Fig. 4 . The isotherm showed type III isotherm with H3 type hysteresis loop. It indicated the presence of slit like pores of nanoscale dimensions in the MgO sample. This is supported by the BJH pore size distribution plot [54] derived from the desorption data, which is shown in the inset of Fig. 4. From this pore size distribution plot it is clear that the MgO material has a bimodal pore size distribution with a narrow peak pore centered at 4.0 nm and a comparatively broad distribution centered 18.0-20.0 nm. The estimated BET surface area, peak pore diameter and total pore volume of the MgO material are 34.2 m2 g−1, 18.8 nm, 0.55 cm3 g−1 respectively. 3.1.5 TPD-CO2 analysis The surface basic site of the MgO sample has been estimated using TPD-CO2 (temperature programmed desorption of carbon dioxide) analysis in the temperature region of 25–575 °C. In Fig. 5 TPD-CO2 profile of MgO nanomaterial is shown. It is noticed from the TCD signal versus temperature profile diagram in Fig. 5 that there are two sharp peaks at 126 and 498 °C. The first and second peaks indicate the existence of weak and strong basic sites [55] in this MgO sample, which are 1.02 and 0.625 mmol g−1, respectively. The total basic strength of the material have been evaluated to be 1.645 mmol g−1. 3.1.6 Microscopic analysis To get an idea about the morphology and the porous nature of the MgO material we have performed field emission scanning electron microscopic (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopic (TEM) analyses. The FESEM images of the MgO sample are shown in Fig. 6 a and b at two different resolutions. From those images sheet like morphology of the MgO material is observed and it is noticed that the MgO nanoparticles are agglomerated in a 2D fashion leading to the sheet like morphology of the sample. In a probable growth process, the free ions (NO3 −, OH−) present in the reaction mixture during the synthesis of the as-prepared sample are adsorbed on the major crystallographic plane of the material surface through hydrogen bonding or through loose coordination with Mg+2 [45]. Hence, growth of MgO occurs in a two dimensional direction leading to formation of sheet like morphology. HRTEM images of MgO sample at two different magnifications are shown in Fig. 7 a and b, which suggested the inter-particle porosity for this MgO nanomaterial. Fig. 7c and d represents the fringes and SAED pattern of MgO sample, respectively. The SAED image indicates the polycrystalline nature of the MgO particles together with different diffraction planes. The EDAX pattern of the material is shown in Fig. 8 . As seen from this pattern that the constituent elements, e.g. Mg and O are present and their stoichiometry has been retained at different parts of the specimen. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Synthesis of cyclic carbonates catalyzed by MgO The calcined MgO material has been employed as heterogeneous catalyst for the CO2 fixation on epoxides in the presence of Bu4NBr (TBAB) for the synthesis of five-membered organic cyclic carbonates (Scheme 1 ). The reaction of epichlorohydrin and carbon dioxide to epichlorohydrin carbonate is selected as the model reaction (Table 1 ). In order to optimize the yield of the five-membered cyclic carbonate, we have checked major parameters including reaction time and amount of TBAB (Table 1). The reaction time and the amount of TBAB both played very crucial role in this cycloaddition reaction as shown in Table 1. The amount of TBAB has been varied and the best yield for the epichlorohydrin carbonate was obtained by using 1.0 mmol TBAB (Table 1, entry 1). Reactions with more and less than 1.0 mmol of TBAB showed incomplete conversion of epichlorohydrin and gave relatively lower yield of the carbonate product (Table 1, entries 5–7). The reaction showed moderately good yield only in one hour reaction time (Table 1, entry 4). With increasing time of the reaction, the yield of the reaction increases (Table 1, entries 1–4) and the reaction was completed only in 4 h reaction time with a very high yield of the desired product (entry 1). It is also observed from Table 1 that only trace amount of the desired carbonate product was obtained in absence of TBAB and the catalyst MgO (Table 1, entries 8 and 9). After checking all the parameters, the optimized reaction condition was obtained with 99% yield of epichlorohydrin carbonate product by carrying out the reaction with 1.0 mmol TBAB at room temperature for 4 h using 25 mg of catalyst and 1.0 atmospheric pressure of CO2 (Table 1, entry 1). We have checked the effect of reaction time on epichlorohydrin to epichlorohydrin carbonate conversion using MgO catalyst and the data is shown in Fig. 9 . A very fast conversion was observed with increasing reaction time. The conversion increased linearly with reaction time for the first 4 h of reaction and then it remained constant at 99% of conversion for the next 3 h of reaction time. Whereas the selectivity of the epicholorohydrin carbonate product remained approximately 100% throughout the entire reaction period. So, Fig. 9 confirmed that 4 h reaction time is sufficient to carry out this chemical fixation of CO2 onto the epoxides at room temperature over nanocrystalline MgO surface. We have also checked the catalytic activity of commercial available MgO catalyst for the synthesis of epichlorohydrin carbonate. It showed only 32% yield of the carbonate product (Table 1, entry 10). The CO2 fixation reaction using MgO catalyst was carried out on a wide range of epoxides like allyl glycidyl ether, glycidyl isopropyl ether, aryloxy epoxide(1, 2-epoxy-3-phenoxy propane), epichlorohydrin and styrene oxide. These epoxides were used as substrates under optimised conditions. From the summarise experimental results as shown in Table 2 , it is observed that most of the aliphatic terminal epoxides showed high yield of five-membered organic cyclic carbonates with high selectivity (Table 2, entries 1–3). On the other hand, the aromatic terminal epoxides showed much poorer yield even after 8 h of reaction (Table 2, entries 4,5). It is also observed from Table 2 that introduction of only 1 ml of DMF as a solvent in the reaction systems with aromatic terminal epoxides, increased the reaction rates and the reactions were completed in only 4 h with high yield as well as high selectivity (Table 2, entries 6,7). The proposed mechanism for the CO2 fixation reaction over epoxides forming five-membered cyclic carbonates in the presence of MgO nanocatalyst is shown in Fig. 10 . The Mg2+ sites on the surface of the MgO catalyst act as Lewis acidic sites which activate the epoxides and undergo non-covalent interactions with the epoxide oxygen atoms. On the other hand, O2− sites of MgO act as Lewis basic sites which activate the carbon dioxide molecules. TBAB provides the leaving group Br− which promotes the formation of the respective cyclic carbonate through the ring opening reaction. As seen from Fig. 10 that TBAB interacts with MgO catalyst and forms a halo-alkoxide. Then CO2 attacks the metal alkoxide bond forming a metal carbonate, which produces the five-membered cyclic carbonate through an intra-molecular ring-closer reaction step. This intra-molecular reaction step and the large number of open active sites present at the MgO surface [45] may cause the exceptionally high catalytic activity of MgO catalyst. 3.2.2 Synthesis of N-formylated amines catalysed by MgO The MgO catalysed N-formylation reaction between amines and formic acid in presence of acetonitrile as solvent is shown in Scheme 2 . The reaction between aniline and formic acid is selected as the model reaction (Table 3 ). In order to optimize the yield of the N-formylated product, we have checked the parameters like reaction time and the presence of different solvents (Table 3). It is observed from Table 3 that, when the reaction was carried out at room temperature in the absence of any solvent for 12 h, the yield of the desired N-formylated aniline was 67% (Table 3, entry 1). It is also observed from Table 3 that keeping the other reaction conditions same, introduction of acetonitrile in the reaction mixture as a solvent enhanced the reaction rate considerably (Table 3, entries 2–5). The reaction was carried out using different solvents such as acetonitrile (CH3CN), ethanol (C2H5OH), methanol (CH3OH) and dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) for 20 min at room temperature (Table 3, entries 5–8). Among the solvents acetonitrile showed the highest yield for the desired N-formylated product. In the presence of acetonitrile the reaction showed 49% yield of the desired product only in 5 min (Table 3, entry 2) and the reaction completed within 20 min with 99.5% yield of the desired product (Table 3, entry 5). Further, in the absence of any catalyst only trace amount of product was obtained (Table 3, entry 9). This result suggested that this N-formylation of aniline over MgO nanomaterial is purely catalytic in nature. After checking the parameters, the optimised reaction condition was obtained with 99.5% yield of N-formylated aniline product by carrying out the reaction with 8 ml acetonitrile at room temperature for 20 min with 60 mg of catalyst(Table 3, entry 5). The N-formylation reaction using mesoporous MgO catalyst was carried out on a variety of amines like aniline, benzyl amine, hindered amine (N-methyl aniline), heterocyclic amine (morpholine), amine with electron withdrawing group (m-choloro aniline) and aliphatic amine (n-butylamine). These amines were used as substrates under optimised conditions, listed in Table 4. It is observed that most of the amines including amine with electron withdrawing group (Table 4 , entry 4) showed high yields of the respective N-formylated products. The hindered amine and aliphatic amine showed comparatively slower reaction with comparatively poor yield of 65% and 52% respectively (Table 4, entry 2, 6). For the heterocyclic amine, only trace amount of product was obtained even after 5 h of reaction (Table 4, entry 5). It is previously reported that higher carboxylic acids other than formic acid are more resistant to formylation [56]. It was found that the reactions of anilines with acetic acid and propionic acid produced only the corresponding amides in moderate yields after long reaction times at high reaction temperature. The proposed mechanism for the MgO catalyzed N-formylation reaction of amines is shown in Fig. 11 . This reaction depends on the Lewis acid-base property of MgO and follows the acid-catalyzed condensation reaction mechanism. HCO2H can be adsorbed on the Lewis acidic Mg+2 sites of MgO. Then the lone pair present in the amine does the nucleophilic attack to the carbon atom of formic acid, which leads to dehydration from the complex forming the respective N-formylated product. 3.3 Recyclability of MgO catalyst At the end of the reaction, the MgO catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The solid catalyst was then washed with DI water and ethyl acetate for several times to remove the impurities and dried in air oven at 60 °C for 6 h. The catalyst has been recycled for five consecutive cycles and after the fifth cycle the MgO material has been characterized by powder XRD and FTIR spectroscopic analysis. As seen from Fig. 1c the cubic MgO phase has been retained in the reused catalyst. Further, FTIR data (Fig. 2) suggested the retention of framework and bonding in the used MgO catalyst. The recycled catalyst was successfully recovered and used to obtain cyclic carbonate and N-formamide in optimised conditions for five times without any significant change in yields for both the products, which are shown in Fig. 12 . This observation suggests that MgO nanocatalyst is heterogeneous in nature and have excellent recycling ability for CO2 fixation and N-formylation reactions. A comparative study of our catalyst and reaction conditions with some other related reported catalytic systems are shown in Table 5 . It is observed from the study that MgO nanocatalyst showed better catalytic efficiency under optimised conditions for both cyclic carbonate synthesis using CO2 and N-formamide synthesis reaction using HCO2H. 4 Conclusion We have synthesized MgO based nanomaterial having mesoscopic void space through a very simple and cost effective precipitation method. The MgO nanomaterial acts as an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides in the presence of CO2 under atmospheric pressure at room temperature. Further, the MgO nanocatalyst showed excellent catalytic activity for N-formylation of amines using HCO2H as reagent and high selectivity for the N-formylated products under mild reaction conditions. The MgO catalyst showed very high recycling efficiency for both these CO2 cycloaddition and N-formylation reactions, suggesting huge potential of porous MgO material in sustainable heterogeneous catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Chemical fixation of CO2 into fine chemicals is one of the key areas of research today to mitigate greenhouse gas CO2 and its successful utilization as C1 building block. Nanocrystalline MgO has been synthesized by simple precipitation method followed by calcination at 450 °C. The materials are characterized thoroughly by several instrumental tools, which suggested the presence of mesoscopic void space and excellent catalytic activity for the synthesis of organic cyclic carbonates by chemical fixation of CO2 on a wide range of epoxides at atmospheric pressure and room temperature within a short reaction time. Maximum product yields upto 99% for the cyclic carbonates are observed. It also displayed a high catalytic activity in the N-formylation of various amines by using formic acid as reagent (acts both as carbon source and reducing agent) at room temperature with excellent product yields upto 99.5%. This nanocrystalline MgO material showed high recycling efficiency for the cycloaddition of CO2 onto the epoxides and no sign of catalyst deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Magnesium oxide as an efficient catalyst for CO2 fixation and N-formylation reactions under ambient conditions
